Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Hirata will undertake a study which will solve for the cosmological recombination history. Without this new recombination calculation, cosmological constraints from the Cosmic Microwave Background will in the near future be limited by the ability to make theoretical predictions, rather than by experimental limitations. Major components of the project include a detailed investigation of many processes that have been previously neglected or considered only in crude or unphysical approximations, including two-photon decays, Raman scattering, Lyman-alpha diffusion, overlap of high-order Lyman lines, and the role of very highly excited levels of the hydrogen atom. The second component will be development of a fast, accurate recombination code suitable for inclusion into CMB prediction software.

Broader impacts of this work include research training for graduate students and release of software to the astronomical community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project carried out a theoretical investigation of the recombination epoch -- the period of time about 300,000 years after the Big Bang at which the Universe expanded and cooled so that neutral atoms (with electrons bound to the nuclei) could form instead of having an ionized plasma (where electrons are detached from nuclei). The recombination epoch is important to cosmology because ionized gas is opaque whereas neutral gas is transparent. Since the Universe is 14 billion years old, the recombination epoch is visible in any direction if we look 14 billion light-years away. The plasma in the early Universe is observed in the microwave part of the spectrum because the expansion of the Universe has stretched the primordial radiation to very long wavelengths. This remnant radiation is known as the cosmic microwave background, and several satellites and ground-based telescopes have been dedicated to measuring its properties very accurately. The ripples in the microwave background acts can be used to do seismology on the early Universe, accurately measuring the abundance of normal and dark matter as well as the initial conditions of the Universe. The next major step forward for this subject will be the Planck satellite mission (led by the European Space Agency with support from NASA), which was launched in 2009 and is scheduled for a data release in 2013.

In order to interpret the microwave background data, it is necessary to have an accurate model of the recombination epoch itself that describes the opacity of the early Universe given a set of model parameters (e.g. the dark matter density). The parameters can then be adjusted until they agree with the data; the range of values that agree with the data constitute a measurement of that property. This is where atomic physics comes in. Only two elements were produced in large quantities in the Big Bang (hydrogen and helium), but they have many energy levels and the interplay of electrons attaching to the atoms and moving between energy levels while absorbing and emitting ultraviolet radiation is a formidable physics problem. Our group has developed several computer codes to do this calculation and cross-check it several times.

The results for one of our models are shown in the attached figure. The vertical axis is the free electron abundance xe, defined as the number of free (i.e. not attached to an atom) electrons for every hydrogen nucleus. It is 0 for purely neutral gas, 1 if the hydrogen is fully ionized, and can be as high as 1.16 if the helium is fully ionized as well (there are 0.08 helium nuclei for every hydrogen, and helium has 2 electrons whereas hydrogen has only 1). The horizontal axis is the redshift z -- the astronomer's most common measure of the size of the Universe. (By definition, if z=1000, then the Universe was 1+z=1001 times smaller at that time than it is today. Note that redshift runs backwards: higher redshift means the Universe was smaller, so it corresponds to an earlier time. Thus in this plot time runs from right to left.) Calculations such as these, with theoretical uncertainties of <0.2%, will enable us to fully realize the potential of the Planck satellite data to measure the properties of the Universe in which we live.
